contentrichtext.text: {{Distinguish|Christianity}} {{wiktionary|Christianism}} '''''Christianism''''' had various definitions over the years. It was originally defined as [[Christian religion|"the Christian religion"]] or "the Christian world",<ref>http://www.thefreedictionary.com/Christianism</ref> with cognates in languages like [[Spanish language|Spanish]] ({{lang|es|cristianismo}}) or [[french language|French]] ({{lang|fr|christianisme}}) retaining this meaning. In recent years, ''Christianism'' (or ''Christianist'') has also been used as a descriptive term of Christian fundamentalists, mostly in the [[USA|United States]], for the ideology of the [[Christian right]], meant as a counterpoint to "[[Islamism]]".<ref name="safire" /><ref name="Walker05202005">{{cite journal|last=Walker|first=Ruth|date=May 20, 2005|title=Onward, Christianist soldiers?|journal=[[Christian Science Monitor]]|publisher=The Christian Science Monitor|location=Boston, Massachusetts|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/2005/0520/p18s04-hfes.html|accessdate=January 31, 2010}}</ref> Writing in 2005, the ''[[New York Times]]'' language columnist [[William Safire]] attributed the term (in its modern usage) to [[Conservatism|conservative]] blogger [[Andrew Sullivan]], who wrote on June 1, 2003 :<ref name="safire">{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2005/05/15/magazine/15ONLANGUAGE.html|title=Isms and Phobias |last=Safire|first=William|date=May 15, 2005 |work=New York Times|accessdate=January 29, 2010}}</ref> <blockquote>I have a new term for those on the fringes of the religious right who have used the Gospels to perpetuate their own aspirations for power, control and oppression: Christianists. They are as anathema to true Christians as the Islamists are to true Islam.</blockquote> The [[Modern liberalism in the United States|liberal]] bloggers Tristero and [[David Neiwert]] used the term shortly after.<ref>[http://tristero.blogspot.com/2003_06_01_tristero_archive.html#200373904 When Semantic Differences Are Not: Part Two] Tristero, June 2, 2003, accessed January 31, 2010.</ref><ref>[http://dneiwert.blogspot.com/2003/06/how-about-christianism.html How about Christianism?] David Neiwert, June 8, 2003, accessed January 31, 2010.</ref> Sullivan later expanded on his usage of the term in a ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine column.<ref>Sullivan, Andrew (May 7, 2006).[http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,1191826,00.html "My Problem with Christianism"], ''Time'', accessed January 31, 2010.</ref> Uses of the term can be found dating back to the seventeenth century, but these are unrelated to its modern meaning.<ref name="safire" /> Christianism has started to gain a foothold in the [[United Kingdom]] too, according to one commentator.<ref>[http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2012/feb/22/catholic-church-reject-uk-christians-persecuted ''Catholic Church leader rejects claim UK Christians are persecuted''], Andrew Brown, ''[[the Guardian]]'', 22 {{dabbr|Feb|February}} 2012 (accessed 22 {{dabbr|Feb|February}} 2012)</ref> == See also == {{portal|Christianity|Politics}} * [[Dominionism]] * [[Theoconservatism]] == Notes == {{reflist}} [[Category:Christian fundamentalism]] [[Category:Conservatism in the United States]] [[Category:American political neologisms]] [[Category:Words coined in the 2000s]] {{poli-term-stub}} {{christianity-stub}}
